Award.AwardTitle: EAGER-Forgotten N-conjugate cytokinins and their active role during senescence
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cytokinin is a plant hormone that is essential to normal growth and development in plants. One key function of cytokinin is to keep older leaves green and growing efficiently by delaying their eventual yellowing and aging, called senescence. Study of how cytokinin regulates the delay of senescence will help researchers learn how to increase growth, performance, and yield of agricultural crops. Cytokinin is a blanket term for a class of about 30 chemically related compounds that regulate these growth processes. A sub-group of understudied cytokinin compounds, known as N-conjugate cytokinins, are also involved in delaying leaf senescence, yet their role and function are unknown. These N-conjugate cytokinins have not been examined for nearly 35 years and only recently were identified as being active regulators of this developmental process. This research aims to understand the role of these forgotten cytokinins in leaf aging using classical bioassays and physiological measurement paired with cutting edge analyses. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in basic research, and summer research experiences will be offered to high school students to increase exposure to the plant sciences.

Nearly all cytokinin research has focused on cytokinin bases forms like trans-Zeatin (tZ) and isopentenyladenine (iP), which are known to bind cytokinin receptors and trigger canonical cytokinin responses, such as delaying senescence. Yet recently findings indicate that the unstudied N-conjugate cytokinins forms can also delay senescence suggesting a re-examination of the role of these N-conjugate during senescence. Bioassays will be used to directly measure changes in the levels of all cytokinin forms and will use GC-MS/MS to determine effects on the cytokinin biosynthesis pathway during development. Transcriptome and proteome analyses during senescence will be conducted in parallel with physiology and measurements of cytokinin levels to characterize gene expression and protein changes that specifically occur in response to N-conjugate cytokinin vs base cytokinin forms. This high risk and high reward endeavor should uncover the role of these otherwise under-studied cytokinins and explain how different cytokinin compounds delay senescence at the molecular level over development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to determine if, where, and when N-conjugated cytokinins function in senescence. Cytokinin is a plant hormone involved in many aspects of plant growth and development. One well-know functional role of cytokinin in plants is its ability to delay senescence, perhaps most easily seen if cytokinin is added to a cut leaf, which results in the leaf staying greener, and photosynthesizing longer than a non-treated leaf. Interestingly how cytokinin functions to specifically delay this process is not fully understood. Part of this project was to better understand how this works and the genes involved in controlling this process. Additionally, the hormone cytokinin is not a single chemical, but has around 30 different naturally occurring chemical forms. There are four base forms that are largely thought of as the active forms, which control all cytokinin functions: trans-zeatin, isopentenyladenine, dihydrozeatin, and cis-zeatin. Interestingly, these base forms are only 1-2% of the total cytokinin found in plants. Most cytokinin is in N-conjugated forms, or base forms where a glucose has been added or conjugated to the N7 or N9 position. For nearly 35 years, these N-conjugated cytokinins have been thought of as inactive storage forms that were not involved in cytokinin functions. However, recently it was shown by the PI and others that N-conjugated cytokinin forms could function as “active” cytokinins in some roles. This proposal further examined to a greater extent if and how N-conjugated cytokinin might function in delaying leaf senescence.

               A careful examination of N-conjugated cytokinin treatments, including different dose ranges using a classic cytokinin bioassay, dark induced leaf senescence assay, revealed that all 11 N-conjugated cytokinins tested were able to delay leaf senescence similar to base cytokinin forms. This was shown by examining leaf senescence at multiple time points across a six day (144 hour) time course for loss of photosynthetic efficiency (Fv/Fm) as well as chlorophyll content. Levels of these senescence measures were equal across all cytokinins, base and conjugates, tested at 144 hours and significantly higher than control leaves.

               Additional analysis of changes in expression of both genes and proteins were analyzed from samples taken at the same time points and treatments as conducted for the physiology in transcriptomic and proteomic experiments. These reveal a number of interesting findings related to this process. From the transcriptome, the timing of cytokinin response for all cytokinin base treated sample occurred at the earliest time points examined, 2 hours, where a set of well recognized cytokinin induced genes were seen as induced. Large numbers of genes continued to be induced at 48 and 96 hours after treatment, with a sharp reduction in altered genes at the final time point. N-conjugated treatments were also able to induce many well recognized cytokinin regulated genes, but this primarily occurred at the last time points. Since both base and N-conjugated cytokinin treatments were able to delay leaf senescence it indicated that both of these different patterns of gene induction can regulate the final physiological outcome. There were also a number of unique N-conjugate regulated genes, which will be interesting to further explore in the future. The proteome findings revealed more distinction between cytokinin bases and N-conjugates, although with some overlap to the gene regulation. Perhaps most interesting was a strong regulation of both N-conjugates and bases at the early 2 hour time point, revealing that there is N-conjugate function as early stages. There was also a general decrease in protein changes at the middle stages 48-96 hours, which return at the final time point. Overall many novel genes and proteins were identified in this analysis as connected to senescence, cytokinin, and specific cytokinin forms.

               There was training of three graduate students and four undergraduate students on this project. All of them were involve in data generation and presented these findings at several regional, national, and internation meetings resulting in poster and oral presentations as well as manuscripts that are published or currently under review for publication. These trainees also participated in several outreach activities, such as Summer Science Institute and Destination STEM to convey science to local elementary and high school students.
